I recently ran into a very strange bug that occurs in JUnit.  I have
reported the bug to SUN, but they directed here, since this behaviour does
not occur in a simple standalone class.

Attached is the unit test that I ran, as well as the output.  Note
especially the third line:

    Class Byte:  Success means that 128 > 127

What I have found is that when a byte variable is defined as a class
variable within a unit test and then incremented, it is possible to
increment it out of the range of bytes specified by the language
specification in two aspects:

1 - Converting the byte to a string results in the string "128"

2 - Comparation states that the byte is larger than Byte.MAX_VALUE
    ( (classByte > Byte.MAX_VALUE) is true )

As the log shows, this test passes in my setup, and I have tried it on
several computers.  Could someone in the know run this test and see if you
can figure out what is going on, because I am totally lost in this.

Thanks and regards,

Magnus Torfason

------------- Standard Output ---------------
    Local Byte:  Success means that -128 == -128
    Static Byte: Success means that -128 == -128
    Class Byte:  Success means that 128 > 127
    Class Short: Success means that 32768 > 32767
